results.title: Woomera 2002
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Anthony Snowden and Laurel Heisman
results.brief_description: During Easter 2002, activists from around Australia converged upon Woomera Detention Centre to protest the federal government’s mandatory detention of refugees. Activists coordinated with the detainees’ protests within the detention centre, resulting in the mass breakout of 50 refugees. Most of the escapees were returned to the detention centre, but 11 detainees achieved freedom. The activists continued to protest the inhumane treatment of refugees in detention throughout the weekend, expressing their solidarity with both the detained refugees and also the people that escaped. This incident led to an increase in global awareness surrounding mandatory detention policies in Australia

results.title: Woomera 2002
results.brief_description: Woomera is a notorious mandatory detention centre in South Australia, a particularly arid and inhospitable part of the desert. In 2002, about one thousand people gathered at Woomera to protest about the Government’s policy of mandatory detention for asylum seekers. When the protestors erect a temporary camp two hundred metres from the centre, the federal police arrive to dismantle their efforts; when they meet resistance, a scuffle ensues. Despite this, the protestors make it over to the interior camp fence and talk to the detainees, who are clearly perturbed and distressed by their ongoing imprisonment. A chaotic scene ensues with detainees attempting to escape, aided by the protestors, as the police try to stop the action. This locally made work is a telling document about a particularly contentious chapter in Australian history that continues to divide opinions about this policy.

results.title: Woolloomooloo
results.brief_description: A social and historical documentary on the redevelopment of one of Sydney’s oldest harbourside areas, from the initial plans of 1969 to the completion of the Housing Commission’s renovation project in late 1977. Details the roles of local, State and Federal governments, the State Planning Authority, The National Trust, the developers, the Builders’ Labourers Federation led by Jack Mundey, and the residents groups.

results.title: Woollen piece
results.creator_credit: Arthur Everard and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: This film shows the rounding up of sheep, droving, shearing, hand carding, spinning and weaving by a variety of people, dyeing, design and the finished products. With virtually no commentary, the film relies on excerpts from lectures on spinning and weaving, design, tapestry etc. to make its points. Scenes of New Zealand are interspersed throughout.

results.title: Woolen goods
results.brief_description: Traces the sources of wool; contrasts methods of shering, cvarding, spinning and waving homespun and factory-made woollens; and follows through the operation involved in making an overcoat from the preliminary testing of the fabrics to the final pressing of the coat and its sale.

results.title: Wool: from sheep to clothing
results.brief_description: A sheep ranch in Montana, USA, a spinning plant in Illinois; and a knitting mill in Wisconsin are studied in turn to show children how the sweaters and socks other woollen clothing they wear are grown and produced.

results.title: Wool testing developments
results.brief_description: This film during the first few minutes shows the sale of wool and the post-sale testing of wool when sold by traditional methods. It then examines new testing systems being developed by the CSIRO for the more efficient objective measurement of wool. Appraisal trails carried out by the Australian Objective measurement Project to determine the feasibility of sale by sample are also examined. During these examinations, the “grab sampler” and the core sampler are featured.

results.title: Wool promotion
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: Deals with various activities of the Australian Wool Bureau in promotiong the use of wool both in Australia and through the International Wool Secretariat, in London, Europe and America. Illustrates the use of looms and project materials in schools, the use of instructional films for wool growers; sales promotion in retail stores.

results.title: Wool in Australia
results.creator_credit: Institut für Film und Bild and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description: Describes life in the Australian outback and the living conditions of a family who raise sheep. Shows shearing, wool sorting, grading, baling and shipping to city markets for auction.

results.title: Wool Fashion Awards of 1960
results.brief_description: Every year, a fashion contest to promote wool as a fabric is held by the Australian Wool Bureau. In 1960, Melbourne compered the awards and this film shows many of the winning entries in the fifty-five sections. Those modelled include suits, coats, dresses, knitwear and slacks. The supreme award for 1960 is the climax of the parade of gold medal winners, held at the end of four days judging.
